sectionTitle: Valuing Level Cash Flows: Annuities and Perpetuities

columns.text: This exercise will determine how much we can withdraw if we have $2,500,000, which earns an 8% interest rate and make an annual payment for 35 years. Additionally, we will also identify how much we can withdraw if they are in the form of an ordinary annuity.

First, let's determine the amount we can withdraw by calculating the annuity payment. Using the prescribed website's financial calculator will result in an amount based on the form of an annuity due.

The annuity due or payment refers to the cash flow received at the beginning of the period. We'll calculate the annuity payment using a spreadsheet function known as PMT to arrive at a similar result. Hence, we'll use the following syntax of the PMT function:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represents the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

Proceeding with the calculation, we'll take into account the following factors:

| Particulars   |            |
|---------------|------------|
| Present value | $2,500,000 |
| Rate          | 8%         |
| Period        | 35         |

Let's now compute the withdrawable amount.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/6539a41b-d42a-46cf-8efe-10a4403090a4-1652166256792161.png)

**After entering the principal amount, the interest rate, and the period, the calculation shows that the amount we can withdraw annually is $198,618.67.**

Next, we will determine the amount payout if withdrawals are in the form of an ordinary annuity. 

The primary difference between an ordinary annuity and an annuity due is that payments with an ordinary annuity occur at the end of the year; on the other hand, annuity due payments are computed at the beginning of the year. Hence, ordinary annuities calculations often have a higher value than the annuity due computation.

In calculating the ordinary annuity payment, we will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Ordinary annuity} &=\dfrac{r\times PV}{1-\left(1+r\right)^{-n}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$r$, which represents the interest rate
$PV$, which refers to the present value cash flow
$n$, which symbolizes the

Last, we will determine the difference in the amount we can withdraw under annuity due and ordinary annuity computation, we will consider the results from our previous steps. To determine the net difference, we will deduct the annuity due amount from the ordinary annuity amount.

To conclude, we have determined that the withdrawable amount is $198,618.67 using a financial calculator of an annuity due. However, if we calculate the payout using the ordinary annuity, we will have a withdrawable amount of $214,508.26, which has an increase of $15,886.59.
